pros:
- Fun and loving colleagues who are there to support and encourage you.
- Knowledgeable seniors who mentor and guide.
- High Tolerant company.
cons:
-It is disappointing to learn that despite being an IT company, there is not much automation nor is there a willingness to upgrade or change the process. Most of the internal processes that existed 10 years ago are still being applied today. Papers are being printed repeatedly for every single orders. Therefore, leading to a huge wastage of papers and resources to handle a dinosaur age company. 

-The Finance department staff are poorly trained and the process is a mess. Employees who are not in the finance department ARE handling Finance issues. 

- Managers care more about satisfying customer's demands than the staff's well-being. And that most of the managers are old employees that have abandoned the technical portion and focused only on the managing portion.

pros:
- Good exposure across different facets of the business, especially operations. 
- Hint of process/work like balance improvements
- Challenging environment offers a great learning platform for improving those fire fighting skills, against both the business and people.  
- Competitive compensation usually on par or better than market.
cons:
- Lack of appreciation wreaks havoc on morale, especially when coupled with prevalent finger-pointing, belittling by management. High turnover observed.
- Friction amidst Business units limit effective collaboration 
- 14 to 20 hour days during crunch time. Deadlines can be extremely tight, made worse by excessive demands.

pros: Culture of flexible working hours, not too strict on arrive to work on the dot.
cons: Understaffed. Everyone is working the workload of at least 2 person. Does not have a clear direction for their staff. Feels like there is no focus and the higher management is just throwing work to whoever that is free instead of whoever is best suited for the job/project.

pros:
- work-life balance. Majority of the people leave on time.
- benefits are ok

This is a good and stable company overall. People who are in the mid~later stage of their careers would stay here until they retire.

- unspoken rule that japanese staff gets better treatment/priorty. I guess this is to be expected since it is a Japanese Company.
- slow career progression. If you are good at something, management will want to keep you there forever.

job_title: IT Technical Support Specialist in Braga
pros: Good working conditions, office schedule from Monday to Friday. Good meal allowance and health insurance.
cons: Training is far for being suitable and complete. You are placed in the desk frontline without being prepared to deal with most of issues that come across during the day. Floowalking assistance and support with difficulties in general not good, unless you have nice colleagues that care to help. You feel completely lost and overwhelmed when you start handling cases. You focus a lot in Fujitsu during initial training and then the training for the project you are being incorporated is short. Base salary 780 because they include language bonus on salary so 730 plus 50 euro from language bonus, which means without language complement, base salary is below the national minimal.

job_title: Senior Project Manager in Bracknell, England
pros: The company has a variety of project delivery opportunities within different sectors, i.e private or public. You can up skill yourself and learn different frameworks. The benefits and the salary are compatible with the current market.
cons: You will have no work-life balance, and be expected to work at the weekend or out of hours when it comes to the migration projects, especially if you are assigned to banking. Bear in mind that you won't get paid overtime for the extra hours that you put in; only take the time off during the week. You will, however, be extremely busy with all of the processes and meetings to which you have been invited. As a result, you must sometimes swallow those extra hours worked.

review_title: Good platform to start career but very HR-oriented and little progression

cons: Easy to get pigeon-held on accounts. Very poor in regards to salary negotiations, very much a battle with HR to get any form of progression. The company is department-centric and as a result it is difficult to feel a part of the company as a whole, particularly apparent when speaking with colleagues cross-department who have vastly different experiences.

review_title: A quick glance at FUJITSU ADVANCED ENGINEERING LIMITED
pros: It's a very place to start a software-engineer career. The company has a 2-year OJT training policy, so everyone will have a chance to learn a lot. They also have good benefits including house support, health insurance, and stock options, ... They even have a work Union inside the company.
cons: They do not have a high salary range. Old Japanese style: people always want to do overtime work for more money. The company also limits the number of overtime one person can do per month. If you're a good engineer, you can do 100 hours of overtime. If you're bad, then no overtime.

pros: If you are capable of human speech you can work here but I wouldn't recommend it. Training is god awful. You'll learn everything you need to know to do the job within the first 2 weeks. Then you wait...and wait...and wait. Hours and hours of doing absolutely nothing You'll be partnered up with someone who also just started taking calls 2 weeks ago. Maybe if you're lucky they'll let you take calls yourself. There was people who were there for months who are still in training as they don't have the right equipment and credentials to take calls yet. Turnover is high. I saw about 5-10 people leave while I was there for various reasons. Network speed on the work devices is unacceptable which leads to poor audio quality on all calls. 90 % of those working there have no IT Skills or training. They only know how to follow written instructions. Users are regularly put on hold for 5 -10 minutes. Instead of attempting to solve or even diagnose the issue, they instead assign it to someone else and hope the user forgets about it. This leaves the 10% of skilled workers doing most of the work for the same pay.
cons: The management, the workers, the agencies, etc

pros: A lot of the people I worked with there were absolutely wonderful, intelligent geniuses.
cons: After proven loyalty to Company they took max 15 days to provide basic reference which meant I lost an absolute gold dust position and possibly my last chance at something worthy of my work built up from my previous 20 year career to the lockdown, without setting my foot in the door of new Company and job cancelled due to lockdown. Managers can veer on toxic, mimicking my voice and also accusing me of thinking about possibly throwing away white board notes from a major team meeting, so being treated like an unruly child with absolutely no provocation to warrant this attitude. Deskilled in order to eventually outsource our jobs over a very long period of time and left feeling unable to move ahead or leave to somewhere better. When ill from an external source not an actual health issue, actually asked if I knew what the arrows were for on a work portal. Having to put up with demeaning and accusatory behaviour over totally imagined attacks, almost paranoid behaviour if you look at it in a certain way but taken out on the wrong people. A lot of passive aggressiveness in competitive situations.

review_title: A good employer but could do better for their employees
pros:
Generally relaxed atmosphere. Good work environment, basically zero office politics (in my area at least). 

People centred company with focus on improving life for employees, customers and the world in general.

Work your way scheme which gives 1 hour of work time back to you for whatever you want.

Company pension contribution is x2 of employee contribution (up to 5% employee & 10% company)
cons:
Shared service model of my job meant that I was working on about 4 teams simultaneously, with four different bosses, not great for productivity in my opinion and was kind of stressful.

Salary was not reflective of the effort I put in either, I was easily able to get salary about 40% higher in another company within only few days of job hunting. Fujitsu did not even attempt to match salary. In this way I think their biggest sin is undervaluing their employees, which causes a decent number to move on when they should ideally be retained. This leads to problems of skills being lost. In IT this will continue to be a problem as more companies are willing to pay better salaries.

I guess in my case they like to ask favours to fill in for missing people, but when you ask for a favour in return they forget what you done in the pass. 
The wages compared to the market are very low (800e Gross) compared to general market.
Also the career progression is very hard, since you team leader has always the last word and approval if you can progress or not, so just be sure to not give them a bad time.

6+ years computers, slow and with old software. they have upgraded only because Windows 7 become unsupported by windows regarding security updates.

job_title: Senior IT Engineer in London, England
pros: Work life balance is good if you can survive on the hugely below market rate pay. Otherwise you'll be doing huge amounts of overtime just to make ends meet.
cons:
They refuse to give inflation rate rises or any sort of London weighting. They demand more and more from you while giving less and less back. Their investment in staff is largely "going through the motions", doing nothing, or as little as possible, while giving the appearance of care. They keep staffing levels low so we're all over worked and have no time to do the rediculous levels of paper work they demand.

If you move on to another role within Fujitsu they flatly refuse to pay you for that role. I've moved from Junior to senior over my time and I'm now earning less than when I started. Appraisals are a pointless waste of time. No matter how good your appraisal is, it's meaningless. If you're doing well they use it as an excuse to increase your workload. While every year that passes is an opportunity to decrease pay. I wish I'd never joined this company.

review_title: Call Center management handling Business Operations?
job_title: Product Manager in Lisbon, Lisbon District
pros:
People
Health Insurance
Office location
Access to online courses/certifications
Remote and/or hybrid work
cons:
INEXPERIENCED LOCAL MANAGEMENT:

Fujitsu's Lisbon GDC has call center managers... because historically, that's the operation that they've handled.

Given some structural changes in the company (ceasing contracts with older employees in a more expensive country and deciding to move operations to a country with "cheaper labour"), these GDC managers got under their wing core areas like:

Business management
Market Intelligence
Business development
Product Management
Technical Consultancy
Partner Partnership programs
Marketing
and many more...

Now I have to say - I am yet to meet such an inept management as the one I met in my time at Fujitsu. 

More often than not, they clearly had no clue what was going on, and the funny thing is - all the employees talked about it. I'm not sure how these ranks could be so oblivious and lacking so much in humility at the same time, when it was obvious for everyone that local management isn't a fit for this project and they're not bringing any value to operations (actually, they are taking value from it be acting as a super effective talent repellent).

I'm sure these people would be fine handling a call centre... but that's stretching my expectations given the displayed ability.

Most of these areas reported to external management outside of the GDC based in other countries, but at the same time everyone had this weird grey area in which they were also reporting to this local GDC management that was absolutely clueless as to what was going on. A really weird and frustrating experience.

NO CAREER OPPORTUNITIES:

These business areas are "new" in the GDC... you'd imagine that would mean growth, but that's not the case because when you're hired, you're most likely already at or close to the "top of the food chain" for your career path, as the GDC does not have further growth for the positions to which they are already hiring for and they won't be available at the GDC (yep, another con they pull at the interviews) you will be stuck doing whatever it is you are doing.

LOW SALARIES THAT IGNORE BENCHMARKS:

As the GDC is used to winning projects by being "competitively priced" in call centre operations, they pay people dirt cheap when compared to market rates and continuously ignore market benchmarks.

This usually ends up happening because they aren't honest on what roles they are hiring for VS the roles people actually are handling - eventually when people figure out they were conned during the hiring process, they start to move away from the company (I'm aware of cases people moving and getting over €1000 more PER MONTH than what FJ offers... that should tell you how low they are paying there).

NO ENCOURAGEMENT, BONUS OR PERFORMANCE AWARDS EVEN WITH SUB-PAR SALARIES:

As stated, the GDC is structurally positioned to handle service desk and call centre operations. Any and all bonus/awards schemes focus around that.

What happens as a result, is that you have people handling core business areas that impact the performance of the company at the EMEA level, and they have zero added benefits, in spite of having a completely disproportionate level of responsibility, even when compared to the local management to whom they have to report to.

There are no performance bonus, no awards - nothing. We're talking about people whose actions bring millions to the company, they spell the success or failure of products. They handle partnerships with major market players, and they drive the bread and butter of business for the EMEA region. They participate in strategic and tactical decisions for the direction of the company in synergy with people both across the region and the HQ in Japan. They generate new partnerships to drive new revenue streams. And they have nothing. 

As the GDC structure wasn't designed to support these core business roles, people in such roles are left aside from any bonus schemes as these were designed to cater to KPI's of service desks/call centres. Local management has no idea what an OKR driven business structure looks like.

It's an obscenely alien concept for the local management to understand, and they won't have any conversations about it - even though most of the people they "manage" in this project have way more responsibility and experience in their hands than this... "management". Management made zero attempts to even understand the different nature of this project VS the call centre ops they are used to and simply discard any constructive conversation or feedback - they were actively resistant to hear what their employees had to say.

Such management, who mostly serve the purpose of approving holidays have: awards, bonuses, company cars and parking spaces to name a few... Why? The extent of their responsibility is literally to relay to their own managers  what the employees are doing (ex.: we have X number of people in Y project doing Z - note that this "doing Z" is based on a very thin understanding of the roles, they have zero understanding of what it is people actually do, they do not follow up on people's tasks nor support them in any way) in the project and approving holidays... they even do a poor job at this. 

About the car - I'm not sure why exactly they would have it. Their job literally means they are sitting at their desk the whole day or working remotely. Other positions which require by their nature visiting partners to generate business do not have such a perk, hence the individual is penalised: either they don't do it and hence do an ineffective job, or they do it out of their own pocket for... hence at a loss, as again - there are no incentives or rewards regardless of your productivity or efforts. 

These managers aren't adding any value to the project, again as stated they are detracting value as they are an extremely poor standard bearer for the project as they continuously misrepresent the support needed locally to the higher C-suite at the GDC, and they do not understand that they are attempting to absorb roles that they are not prepared to support, and that they themselves are not capable, experienced, talented or willing to approach in an effective way.

LOCAL MANAGEMENT VS EXTERNAL MANAGEMENT (Germany):

So I've mentioned a couple of times that people in this project are in a weird grey area... where could I start.

All the coaching/training/support is given by the management & colleagues in Germany. This causes a weird situation, because many of them have a bitter taste in their mouths due them losing these positions to cheaper labour in Portugal... so you can see where this is going.

Some of them are quite supportive and good, others... although having the experience, they don't really care about supporting the staff in Portugal.

Then, the local management has zero ability and willingness to offer support as well. Again, because they have no idea of what's going on, and zero willingness to understand what's going on - their job is just to report what we do in the GDC (at a very high level...) and approve holidays -that's literally it. 
Besides that, they come up with some random power point slides (that in most cases where done by other people) and present them wrapped up in stakeholder meetings, pretending they have even a slight understanding of what is going on with the operation.

Now the interesting thing is - management in Germany tends to be quite happy with the good work people do in Lisbon, even with all this hardship. But apparently, they can't influence our working conditions, and they are aware that they are constantly losing people because employees in Lisbon have sub-par conditions.

So even if you present stellar results, and your ACTUAL MANAGER (the one in Germany) wants to improve your conditions, the GDC does no approve it. Why would these random people whose only contribution to daily ops is to approve holidays, have a say in how much someone should be compensated by their hard work?

It's ridiculous.

But then again, if the project overall has good results because of all these people... you can be sure managers are rewarded.

review_title: Those were the days my friend!
pros:
* The "Fujitsu way" has a great phylosophy and has great vision, but who is following the Fujitsu Way in the management team? Really?!.
*"Human Centric Innovation" made me join Fujitsu
* "Driving a trusted future" made me fight for Fujitsu
* Great opportunities for self learning
* Quality - "REAL" green IT products
* the "REAL" lightest and powerfull noteboks
* powerfull DC and server products which achieved ultimate passmark and test results from several software vendors
* challenging ecosystem
cons:
* lead delivery times
* lack of communication with the management
* pushing for great margins but somehow always failing when it comes to the competition.
* Aprox 25% expensive than any competitors
* no real run rate business because no consumer products but mostly high end-at least outside the Japan
* most of the pretty products are not available outside the Japan.
* Agile phylosophy?...unfortunately everything is slow until it comes to kicking people out, yeah that one is very fast.
* Instead of all cons, Fujitsu is a great company to work and I "still" believe in Fujitsu. On the other hand you have no idea what may happen next week... month... year...things are not stable.
* who is ruling/managing the faith of Fujitsu? There are several faces...inside Japan & outside Japan...anything uotside the Japan is like a big puppet show which you will not enjoy to watch...
* Fujitsu Client Computing Limited ("FCCL") ..perhaps that is the worst thing in the picture.

review_title: Fujitsu - a sad and failing company
job_title: Head Office Staff in Manchester City Centre, England
pros:
Generous pension and benefits because the unions are in charge here

Very slow pace of work because there's no new work coming in and everyone is a 60+
cons:
*Beware the fake positive reviews posted by their HR / PR staff!*

It's hard to know where to begin! Just a truly awful company in every sense of the word, lacking in any direction or ambition, zero diversity, full of geriatric lifers and slowly dying - it will certainly be the next Compaq / Nokia / Blockbuster / PanAm / *insert other extinct consumer brand here*. This place is like a backwater you hope you never have to sail up and once you do you’re stuck. 

This is a VERY dated old fashioned company that has long since had its glory days. Being at Fujitsu is like when you walk around old Olympic Games sites from bygone eras that are just rusting wastelands now and sad reminders of what once was. Fujitsu was maybe once a trendy place to work in the 80s / 90s / early 00s. Now it is just a creaking bureaucracy full of pointless rules and regulations and deskilled workers who stay with the company for the crazy generous benefits (but CRAP pay) and ability to coast / skive / shirk for their entire careers and take zero responsibility or ownership for anything waiting to retire / get culled in the routine reorgs that take place. There is no future for this old tech company and it can’t compete with new tech despite the constant confusing rebranding. 

Another weird thing for a technology company is that nothing ever seems to get done at Fujitsu yet the company seems to get bigger and more bureaucratic year on year. So many pointless “managers” and hoops to jump through to do the most basic things. And Fujitsu “managers” is a very generous way to describe these people. Line managers lack basic people management skills and universally lack any leadership qualities. Mediocrity is accepted as normal here and there is no drive to change or push for quality outcomes. Why would anyone would want to start or try to progress their career at somewhere so lacklustre and uninspiring??? Joining this company should come with a disclaimer!!

There is absolutely zero career progression at this company too as it is not an aspirational place to work. Most people in Fujitsu have been kicking around for years and are extremely lazy and it ends up rubbing off on you as that’s the company culture - do as little as possible and hope no-one finds out. Another weird thing about this being a technology company is that nothing feels modern at all!!! Even the intranet uses an early 00s interface and don’t even get me started on the rusting and decrepit offices. Just run a Google image search for their Bracknell office - what kind of 20 something recent computer science / software engineering graduate is going to want to work in some Soviet era tower block that wouldn’t look out of place in Kiev?! Answer: no-one! This is not a young person’s company. And definitely NOT a place for smart graduates to go! They go to Facebook, Apple, Amazon, Google ; they don’t ruin their careers at have-been hardware companies like Fujitsu…

What is so annoying is how hierarchical and bureaucratic the company is. There is no innovation because you have to go through hundreds of hoops to do anything. Some teams have seemingly never ending reporting lines, I have one current colleague whose reporting line consists of no fewer than EIGHT people. EIGHT people in ONE reporting line. Only at Fujitsu could you have the cast of thousands in a single reporting line - now you see why nothing gets done and the company is losing work! Same thing with internal meetings absolutely EVERYONE has to be involved in every inconsequential decision , customers even point that out to me why are there so many people involved it’s embarrassing. 

There is also no diversity or representation at all at any level of the company and absolutely NONE in the leadership team. Management love to talk about diversity initiatives but there is nothing concrete happening anywhere. Practically everyone who works here is a white British male in their 50s / 60s. It is extraordinary how NOT diverse this company is, unusually so, almost like they actively tried NOT to hire anyone that isn’t a white British 50+ male. 

Do not come here - you will kill your career. If you are there now, get out it gets harder every year to escape because you're so deskilled.

review_title: Struggling to keep up with the industry
pros: It is a former group company of one of the leading Japanese manufacturer, Fujitsu., Ltd. The company manufactures and sales a variety of components, allowing to appeal to a wide range of end-equipments and parts. As a company starting off with relay components, it has a strong connection and background to electricity and telecommunication companies in Japan as well as other electronic component companies. Owning their own factory, and designing their products by themselves, the company has a strong control over the products they manufacture, realizing provision of high quality.
cons: Entering their 20th anniversary, the company culture is starting to become outdated. While the company strives to make flexible moves and tries to change its strategic actions to adapt to the changing market of Japanese electronic component manufacturing, it is struggling to see its effects at the time being. The philosophy of all-the-way-to-the-end by designing in-house, manufacturing internally, and selling by themselves are resulting in high price which further burden them in competition in the market.

Decent headline salary and benefit package in line with industry. Healthcare, flexibility to buy / sell holiday, various support for families.
Wide range of services, industries and customers, so always the chance to move and learn.
cons:
Strategy flip-flops and massive reorganisations every couple of years. Little visible leadership commitment to making things work.
Massively inefficient and bureaucratic. Far too many people people shuffling paper, writing processes and adding no value.
Employees first to feel the bite if the forecasts look gloomy - pay freezes, travel bans, recruitment freezes leading to undermanning
Many benefit levels do not change annually, meaning your overall package deteriorates over time

pros: The people who work there are mostly very friendly - I got on with the majority of my colleagues. There was also some work from home potential
cons:
The graduate scheme is highly competitive and is constantly talked up in the company - however I had an awful time as did many in my cohort, many of whom left as soon as they could. I was given almost nothing to do, was regularly pitted against my peers, was patronised and treated like a child by many of the older men in SLT. The grad scheme element consisted mostly of 8, fairly useless learning modules that we attended over 2 years. Outside of that there was no support from the grad scheme team who were more interested in recruitment than retainment. Nobody checked in from the wider organisation to see how grads were fairing. Many of the grads who I knew suffered massively with mental health due to the poor support and opportunities provided. We were told by Business Unit leadership that we just needed to be more resilient. 
I personally was given very little work to do or responsibility - despite seeking it out regularly. Then was penalised for such in performance reviews.

pros: Not much, maybe one or two friendly staff that will help you when needed.
cons:
In the short time i have worked at Fujitsu, i have found that most but not all staff are not too friendly, most don't even acknowledge or look at you when you greet them. I was not given any training or even an introduction into the process involved to doing my job then they question my numbers are not up to standard, after only 4 weeks? Mind you, they give me the jobs no one else wants to do and then compared my numbers to staff that are doing completely different equipment and who have also been there for a minimum of 3 yrs. I managed to get a "Good work" from a boss higher up, but then get questioned by some "know it all"  in a different state (QLD), he asks if I am doing all necessary tests? You don't question someones work methods after they have been told they are doing a good job, you question them when they are doing poorly then you seek to help them! Not to mention my Team leaders sat there silent and didn't even come to my defence.
They also tried to put the blame on me for a part number being entered into the system incorrectly and wanted me to fix it? Hold on, if you go to the base of the problem, there is a less likely chance for it to happen again. I don't mind correcting it but don't point the finger at me and make me fix it every time it happens!

This may be the most toxic environment i have ever worked at.
